content: "God the Father" is not in the Torah. The scripture indicates that the Lord - Jesus, not God the Father appeared in the form of man before Abraham with two angels and bargained about the fate of Soddom and Gomorrah. (Genesis 18:1-5) Abraham was able to recognize Jesus immediately as is apparent by his actions of running toward Him, bowing and speaking "my Lord". Abraham had met the Lord before (Genesis 12:7) Jesus speaking of God the Father: "No man hath seen God at any time" (1 John 4:12) "Ye have neither heard His voice at any time, nor seen His shape" (John 5:37) So, Abraham had a very real, personal discussion with the person who would later be known as Jesus Christ. Abraham even called Jesus. "the Judge of all the earth" (Genesis 18:23-25) Jacob, later known as Israel, Abraham's grandson had an all night wrestling match with Jesus. The match went on for some time until the breaking of the day. Both were physically adept and the match was extremely close. Jacob's unkown wrestler touched part of his thigh which put it out of joint, but Jacob kept such an iron grasp that the mystery man asked to be freed. Jacob realized the man's true identity and then the man said "Let me go, for it is dawn". Jacob replied "I will not let you go unless you bless me" "What is your name?" the man asked. "Jacob" "Your name will no longer be Jacob" the man said. "It is now Israel, because you have struggled with both God and men, and have won". When Jacob gave a name to this venue, he named the place "Peniel" -"face of God" -for he said "I have seen God face to face, yet my life has been spared". The Old Testament is not about some grouchy, old "God the father", it's about Jesus. The term "angel", is found when Jesus appeared to Moses for the first time: "And the angel of the Lord appeared unto him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush" He said to Moses: "I am the God of thy father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, the God of Jacob". (Exodus 3:2,6) While the God of the Old Testament said "I AM" would be His name forever, Jesus was nearly stoned to death by the Jews for calling Himself "I AM". God was seen and heard many times in the Old Testament, who was it everyone in the Old Testament saw and heard? Jesus is the same God who ordered light to shine from the very beginning, the same God who flooded the earth, the same God who used His finger to write the Ten Commandments into the stone tablets. For those who think Jesus is solely found in the pages of the New Testament, you're only seeing a fraction of the story. - excerpted from Joe Kovacs "Shocked By The Bible" This information really makes the Bible even more powerful for me. It completely bridges the meanings of the laws and proves the Bible maintains the consistent message it promises. It enlightens me to how our God operates and helps me understand the role of Jesus (although adds many questions) and shows even more that He was not merely a "sacrifice" (as many atheists like to say "how could He murder his Son") but an integral part neccessary for our understanding, because let's face it, we were created with great minds and it is an abomination to not attempt to understand the complexities of our Father.

It's my opinion that when Christ came and clarified those laws, he made it even tougher... You commit adultery by thinking about adultery regardless of your actions. Basically, by your inner intent (includes thoughts) you break the laws, regardless of whether you physically do or not. Whoa, for me that means he made it even tougher... But, it was impossible before... Hmmm What if the purpose of the 10 Commandments, the newer clarifications, and our own understanding is not to follow law @ all... I'm beginning to think (influenced by "The Shack") the intent of these laws is more like a reflection for us each to look into and see ourselves as we really are. It gives us a standard to see how far we each individually are moving, and in what direction. I think the NT gives us the freedom we need from the commandments to grow in Spirit and achieve without the anchor of failure from the law... Remember this is strictly my take on this, I do not know much for that matter on any subject. I have learned through my limited studies and experiences that when questions are asked, answers are found. But with every answer, deeper questions appear... I usually don't have the time for all the answers so I need the room to follow my heart. When I do, I find through others that I seem to accomplish things beyond my understanding. If you believe in G-d, and I believe in G-d we are on the same field regardless of our personal beliefs. We should not allow others to influence that... Thanks for listening, it's good to meet you... CJ

content: The need to follow the ten commandments is summed up in the two great commands given by Jesus. The first of which is given in the old testament, look it up. Love the Lord God with all your strength, all your heart , and all your mind. The second is from Jesus Himself. And, love one another as I have loved you, surely if you do these things the doors of Heaven will be open to you. The signifigance of these two must be explained by knowing the ten. The first of the ten commandments concern our relationship to God and His with us. The last concern themselves with our relationships to one another. Therefore the simple admonishment to follow the two great commands, when fully understood, carries the responsibility to follow them all. It is questionable if any human being has ever been able to do that. You have asked this question many times and the covenant with Israel has nothing to do with having a relationship with God for the gentiles. If you want me to justify your following the Noachide laws there is no reason for me to. Nor is there any reason for me to seek your approval for the commands of Jesus given to us, who have the power to claim His name, that he gave to us freely to use in our lives and in the service to, and for, men and mankind. As for the need to follow the six hundred and three "laws" in addition to the ten commandments there is no need to follow them whatsoever by any Christian, You are confusing Christians with Messianic Jews, what ever they are. Now I would ask you a question, why are you so intent on asking this question? You have continually done so as long as you have been on these threads and to my recollection at least have been answered four or more times. This being the fifth?

Sorry, I'm doing it again... To much Christian Theology... I hope that helps... CJ

content: O.K. I will probably regret this, but here goes. Most Christians see the Hebrew faith as the foundation of their own. After all Jesus was a Jew. According to our interpretations of scripture this is bourne out. This being the case, all of the old Testament has meaning for us in understanding the place of the Jews and us in the dual covenants and the Noachide laws as well. The Jews and the Ben Noach see the Christians as illigitimate, and poseurs to the covenant with God given to the Jews. The Messianic Jews and that entire movement has caused incredible strife between all of the three groups. Every time when questioned I have stated time and again that the old covenant still stands for the Jews. But the gentiles were "grafted into the branch" This does NOT mean we have become as Jews, we have not. The coming and ministry of Jesus means that God's salvation is open to all....period. God's not Jesus's, He is the means, but Salvation by Grace, comes from God! Now men can argue and kill each other about this, and they have, but not a single one of us will EVER convince the other which is the "truth", not while alive. I know of no prophetic Jews, I know of no prophetic Ben Noach. I DO know several prophetic Christians, personally, and have seen their work. I will not argue this, I don't ask any to believe it. I believe it and that is all that is required for me. I have seen the proofs, downright miracles in my presence. End of story. If others of other faith systems have seen such things, and those who work them, let THEM bring them forth, I am more than willing to listen, as I believe God works in His way, for ALL people, no matter WHAT they believe. In SPITE of what they believe, for His own reasons. I don't and won't argue this, God does not need me to defend Him. I will NOT defend my beliefs, they don't need me to defend them. Why? Because I don't ask any to believe as I do, that's why. So, since I don't condemn any for whatever they believe, my life is immeasurably simpler and simple is necessary for me to be effective....there again....End of story. Now, if you can not find your answer in there it does not exist! At least not for you, in a form you will accept. T

Jacob's unkown wrestler touched part of his thigh which put it out of joint, but Jacob kept such an iron grasp that the mystery man asked to be freed. Jacob realized the man's true identity and then the man said "Let me go, for it is dawn". Jacob replied "I will not let you go unless you bless me" "What is your name?" the man asked. "Jacob" "Your name will no longer be Jacob" the man said. "It is now Israel, because you have struggled with both God and men, and have won". When Jacob gave a name to this venue, he named the place "Peniel" -"face of God" -for he said "I have seen God face to face, yet my life has been spared". content: The need to follow the ten commandments is summed up in the two great commands given by Jesus. The first of which is given in the old testament, look it up. Love the Lord God with all your strength, all your heart , and all your mind. The second is from Jesus Himself. Jesus NEVER said that Gentiles were to be 'grafted' in Israel. That is Paul's teachings(Rom 11:24). Paul is the one with the idea that thanks to Jesus, gentiles were now part of G-d's plan. As if the Nations (before Jesus) were not important to HaShem!! Few people know anything about the 7 Laws of Noah and how precious they are to HaShem. Very few seem to understand that the first Covenant given by G-d, was with the Nations! Imagine that!! G-d has always loved the Nations! There is no need for the Nations to become grafted into Israel to have a relationship with G-d. Therefore, there is no need for the Nations to try to keep what was given to Israel. Since this a theological discrepancy between Judaism and Christianity, I doubt there will be any agreement on this. Ixcatl
